content:
Cursors Class

Definition

Defines a set of default cursors.

In this Article

public static class Cursors
Inheritance
System.Object
Cursors

Inherited Members

Equals(Object)
Equals(Object,Object)
GetHashCode()
GetType()
MemberwiseClone()
ReferenceEquals(Object,Object)
ToString()

Remarks

This static class defines a set of default cursors common to applications.

The various static properties defining cursors are not directly usable in XAML, but are indirectly used through two possible mechanisms:

  • The Cursor class performs type conversion on any XAML attribute that takes type Cursor, such that a value of the CursorType enumeration specified as the attribute value will evaluate to one of the static Cursors properties.

  • A static property value can be used through the x:Static Markup Extension.

Properties

AppStarting

Gets the Cursor that appears when an application is starting.

public static System.Windows.Input.Cursor AppStarting { get; }
Value
Cursor

The AppStarting cursor.

Remarks

The AppStarting typically indicates that the system is loading information, but the user interface can handle input.

XAML Text Usage

See Remark on Cursors.

Arrow

Gets the Arrow Cursor.

public static System.Windows.Input.Cursor Arrow { get; }
Value
Cursor

The arrow cursor.

Remarks

The arrow Cursor is typically the default cursor.

XAML Text Usage

See Remark on Cursors.

ArrowCD

Gets the arrow with a compact disk Cursor.

public static System.Windows.Input.Cursor ArrowCD { get; }
Value
Cursor

The arrowCd cursor.

Remarks

XAML Text Usage

See Remark on Cursors.

Cross

Gets the crosshair Cursor.

public static System.Windows.Input.Cursor Cross { get; }
Value
Cursor

The Crosshair cursor.

Remarks

This cursor typically appears over regions in which a drawing operation can be performed.

XAML Text Usage

See Remark on Cursors.

Hand

Gets a hand Cursor.

public static System.Windows.Input.Cursor Hand { get; }
Value
Cursor

The hand cursor.

Remarks

The hand Cursor typically indicates the pointer is over a link.

XAML Text Usage

See Remark on Cursors.

Help

Gets a help Cursor which is a combination of an arrow and a question mark.

public static System.Windows.Input.Cursor Help { get; }
Value
Cursor

The help cursor.

Remarks

Typically, this cursor is displayed when context-sensitive help is available.

XAML Text Usage

See Remark on Cursors.

IBeam

Gets an I-beam Cursor, which is used to show where the text cursor appears when the mouse is clicked.

public static System.Windows.Input.Cursor IBeam { get; }
Value
Cursor

The IBeam cursor.

Remarks

XAML Text Usage

See Remark on Cursors.

No

Gets a Cursor with which indicates that a particular region is invalid for a given operation.

public static System.Windows.Input.Cursor No { get; }
Value
Cursor

The No cursor.

Remarks

XAML Text Usage

See Remark on Cursors.

None

Gets a special cursor that is invisible.

public static System.Windows.Input.Cursor None { get; }
Value
Cursor

The none cursor.

Remarks

The None cursor provides a means of hiding the cursor.

XAML Text Usage

See Remark on Cursors.

Gets a pen Cursor.

public static System.Windows.Input.Cursor Pen { get; }
Value
Cursor

The pen cursor.

Remarks

XAML Text Usage

See Remark on Cursors.

The scroll all cursor.

A wait cursor.

Remarks

This Cursor typically indicates that the application is busy performing an operation.

XAML Text Usage

See Remark on Cursors.
